Award.AbstractNarration:
Throughout the history of number theory, a common theme is the unexpected link between arithmetic and analysis. A key unifying concept that links arithmetic and analysis is the notion of an L-function. There are two fundamentally different ways to define L-functions. One way is to count the number of solutions to certain polynomial equations modulo primes, and then to put the resulting numbers into a certain generating function. The other way is to start with highly symmetric solutions to certain differential equations on symmetric manifolds (automorphic forms) and then to define L-functions in terms of these solutions using analysis. The idea of reciprocity in the Langlands program is the conjecture that all L-functions defined in terms of polynomial equations can also be defined in terms of automorphic forms. This conjectural link is expected to have deep implications in both number theory and harmonic analysis. This research project aims to further explore the reciprocity conjecture and its implications.

Some of the most basic interesting classes of L-functions in arithmetic arise from polynomial equations with integer coefficients in two variables (algebraic curves over the rational numbers). Associated to such a polynomial is an invariant g (the genus) which is a non-negative integer. If the genus g is zero, then the resulting L-function can be expressed in terms of the Riemann zeta function, and reciprocity in this case follows from Riemann's work. If the genus g is one, then the reciprocity conjecture is equivalent to the Taniyama-Shimura conjecture, now verified. The goal of this project is to make significant progress on the case when the genus g is two.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The proof of Fermat's Last Theorem by Andrew Wiles in 1994 was a watershed moment for number theory. It was very quickly realized that the techniques developed by Wiles (in part with Richard Taylor) would have wide applicability to a large range of other problems in number theory. In the subsequent 25 years, many authors have built upon these results.

One way to view Wiles' work is in terms of elliptic curves, which are a very special class of polynomial equations with integer coefficients in two variables. These include equations of the form y^2 = f(x) where f(x) is a cubic polynomial. To any polynomial equation in two variables one can associate an invariant g (the genus) which measures their complexity. The equations of genus g=0 have been understood since antiquity. The results of Wiles and Taylor-Wiles can be seen as giving a rich structure to the equations of genus g=1 (such as elliptic curves). While the generalizations of Wiles' work had much to say about complicated systems of polynomial equations in higher dimensions with many variables, the case of equations in two variables of genus g=2 remained open and stubbornly resistant to these methods. One of the main achievements of this project (in joint work with George Boxer, Toby Gee, and Vincent Pilloni) was to push the Taylor-Wiles method to make significant advances in this case. This in turn built on previous work of the PI with David Geraghty which expanded the Taylor-Wiles method in an unexpected direction.

It is hoped that the methods developed in this project will lead to the full generalization of the results of Wiles and Taylor-Wiles for curves of genus g=1 to curves of genus g=2.

A popular account of some of the work of this proposal was featured in Quanta magazine: https://www.quantamagazine.org/amazing-math-bridge-extended-beyond-fermats-last-theorem-20200406/
